leadStory.title: Federal Compliance Operations Expand to 12 New States Ahead of Election
leadStory.summary: The Federal Compliance Office announced Tuesday that it would extend enforcement operations to a dozen additional states, a significant escalation that critics say is designed to influence turnout in contested districts. The expansion, which begins immediately, will nearly double the agency's operational footprint.

leadSecondary.title: What the Compliance Expansion Means for Swing States
leadSecondary.summary: Political analysts say the timing and geography of the FCO's announcement is unlikely to be coincidental, with operations concentrated in areas that could determine control of Congress.
leadSecondary.author: Rachel Morrison

leadSecondary.title: The Algorithms Behind the Crackdown: How AI Decides Who Gets Flagged
leadSecondary.summary: An investigation into the predictive systems reveals technology that is powerful, opaque, and nearly impossible to challenge in court.

midSection.title: AI Adoption Surges Among Small Businesses, But Workers Express Concerns
midSection.summary: Nearly 60% of businesses with fewer than 50 employees now use AI assistants—up from 12% two years ago. But employees say the technology is increasingly used for surveillance.
midSection.author: David Park

midSection.title: Study Finds Operations Disproportionately Target Working-Class Areas
midSection.summary: New research from Columbia finds FCO operations concentrated in zip codes with median incomes below the national average.
midSection.author: David Okonkwo

opinion.title: The Compliance Expansion Is a Stress Test for Democracy
opinion.author: By The Editorial Board
opinion.content: Whatever one's views on immigration enforcement, the timing of this expansion—three weeks before a national election—raises questions that deserve answers. The administration's assurance that operations are "routine" strains credulity. We urge Congress to demand transparency before Election Day.
